verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Jehu son of Hanani against Baasha, saying,
verses.comment: Jehu is a prophet here, not the later king. The introduction follows the Hebrew structure.

verses.text: "Because I raised you up from the dust and made you leader over My people Israel, but you have walked in the way of Jeroboam and have caused My people Israel to sin, provoking Me to anger with their sins,
verses.comment: Consistent with the rebuke formula for kings; 'dust' here as per the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: behold, I will sweep away Baasha and his house, and I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat.
verses.comment: 'Sweep away' is literal to the Hebrew (like sweeping dung).

verses.text: "Anyone belonging to Baasha who dies in the city the dogs shall eat, and anyone of his who dies in the field the birds of the sky shall eat."
verses.comment: Common idiom for dishonorable death; 'sky' for 'heavens' to modernize.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Baasha, what he did, and his might, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Formulaic phrase, mirrored from the Hebrew.

verses.text: And Baasha slept with his fathers and was buried at Tirzah. And Elah his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: 'Slept with his fathers' is the Hebrew euphemism for death.

verses.text: Moreover, the word of the LORD came by the prophet Jehu son of Hanani against Baasha and his house, because of all the evil that he did in the sight of the LORD, provoking Him to anger with the work of his hands, in being like the house of Jeroboam, and also because he destroyed it.
verses.comment: This is a summary of Baasha's judgment and prophet's message.

verses.text: In the twenty-sixth year of Asa king of Judah, Elah son of Baasha began to reign over Israel at Tirzah, and he reigned two years.
verses.comment: Standard date formula as per the original.

verses.text: But his servant Zimri, commander of half his chariots, conspired against him. While Elah was drinking himself drunk in the house of Arza, who was over the household at Tirzah,
verses.comment: 'Commander of half his chariots' is literal; 'drinking himself drunk' modern English for Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Zimri went in and struck him down and killed him, in the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, and became king in his place.
verses.comment: Direct and as literal as possible.

verses.text: When Zimri began to reign, as soon as he sat on his throne, he struck down all the house of Baasha. He did not leave him a single male, either relatives or friends.
verses.comment: 'A single male' is the Hebrew 'one who urinates against the wall.' Paraphrased to modern English, faithful in sense.

verses.text: Thus Zimri destroyed all the house of Baasha, according to the word of the LORD, which He spoke against Baasha by the prophet Jehu,
verses.comment: Declaration of prophecy fulfillment.

verses.text: for all the sins of Baasha and the sins of Elah his son, which they sinned and made Israel to sin, provoking the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger with their idols.
verses.comment: Faithful to Hebrew; 'their idols' clarifies the direct object.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Elah, all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Standard formula; mirrors original.

verses.text: In the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, Zimri reigned seven days in Tirzah. Now the troops were encamped against Gibbethon, which belonged to the Philistines.
verses.comment: Brings forward the siege as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And the troops who were encamped heard it said, "Zimri has conspired and has killed the king." So all Israel that day made Omri, the commander of the army, king over Israel in the camp.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering of the original account.

verses.text: Then Omri and all Israel with him went up from Gibbethon and besieged Tirzah.
verses.comment: Simple, direct translation.

verses.text: When Zimri saw that the city was taken, he went into the citadel of the king's house and burned the king's house over himself with fire and died,
verses.comment: 'Citadel' reflects the stronghold in the Hebrew.

verses.text: because of his sins that he committed, doing what was evil in the sight of the LORD, walking in the way of Jeroboam, and in his sin which he committed, making Israel to sin.
verses.comment: Enumerates his sins as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Zimri, and his conspiracy that he made, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Standard closing formula; literal.

verses.text: Then the people of Israel were divided into two parts: half of the people followed Tibni son of Ginath, to make him king, and half followed Omri.
verses.comment: Clear clause order, matching the original.

verses.text: But the people who followed Omri prevailed over the people who followed Tibni son of Ginath. So Tibni died, and Omri became king.
verses.comment: 'Prevailed over' modern rendering of Hebrew.

verses.text: In the thirty-first year of Asa king of Judah, Omri began to reign over Israel, and he reigned twelve years; six years he reigned in Tirzah.
verses.comment: Follows the original's order of regnal years.

verses.text: And he bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for two talents of silver. He built on the hill and called the name of the city that he built Samaria, after the name of Shemer, the owner of the hill.
verses.comment: 'Samaria' is a play on Shemer's name in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Omri did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, and did more evil than all who were before him.
verses.comment: Repeats the Hebrew superlative with 'more evil than.'

verses.text: For he walked in all the way of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, and in the sins that he made Israel sin, provoking the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger with their worthless idols.
verses.comment: 'Worthless idols' renders Hebrew 'idols' as per context.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Omri that he did, and his might that he showed, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Matches the standard verse formula.

verses.text: So Omri slept with his fathers and was buried in Samaria, and his son Ahab became king in his place.
verses.comment: Follows pattern; 'slept with his fathers' as euphemism for death.

verses.text: In the thirty-eighth year of Asa king of Judah, Ahab son of Omri began to reign over Israel. Ahab son of Omri reigned over Israel in Samaria twenty-two years.
verses.comment: Faithful date/chronology structure.

verses.text: Ahab son of Omri did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, more than all who were before him.
verses.comment: Parallels statement about Omri, but further intensifies it.

verses.text: And as if it had been a trivial thing for him to walk in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, he took as wife Jezebel the daughter of Ethbaal king of the Sidonians, and went and served Baal and worshiped him.
verses.comment: 'Trivial thing' faithful to the Hebrew idiom for minimization.

verses.text: He erected an altar for Baal in the house of Baal, which he built in Samaria.
verses.comment: Faithful word order and content.

verses.text: Ahab also made an Asherah. Ahab did more to provoke the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger than all the kings of Israel who were before him.
verses.comment: 'Made an Asherah' preserves the ambiguity of the Hebrew term for goddess or pole.

verses.text: In his days Hiel of Bethel built Jericho. He laid its foundation at the cost of Abiram his firstborn, and set up its gates at the cost of Segub his youngest son, according to the word of the LORD, which He spoke by Joshua son of Nun.
verses.comment: Mirrors the Hebrew syntax and theological implication; the curse's fulfillment.
